--- title: "Fitting Primary Growth Models" subtitle: "Microbial Shelf Life Assessment Under New Societal Challenges" date: "April 2024" author: - Vasco Cadavez - Ursula Gonzales-Barron - Instituto Politécnico De Bragança tutorial: id: "primary-models" version: 1.0 output: learnr::tutorial: progressive: true allow_skip: true # theme: simplex # highlight: null css: "../css/esafefood.css" bibliography: ../files/esafefood.bib csl: ../files/apa-6th-edition.csl runtime: shiny_prerendered embed-resources: true --- ## Objectives 1. Describe the population growth dynamics of bacterial cultures 2. Measure growth of a bacterial culture 3. Plot a bacterial growth curve 4. Predict the bacterial growth ## Dynamics of the microbial growth - Microbial growth curve - Plotting the cell numbers *versus* incubation time - Require inoculation of viable cells - Incubation under adequate environmental conditions - Temperature - pH - etc. - Under optimal growth conditions - cells will reproduce rapidly ## Microbial growth phases 1. **Lag phase** - cells are **adjusting** to the new environment 2. **Exponential phase** - exponential **increase** in population - doubles regularly until the **maximum** number of cells 3. **Stationary phase** - cells undergoing division **equals** cells that are dying

![](../images/growth.png){width=50%} ## Primary growth models ### Describe the microbial growth - Many different models have been developed - Models **fitted** to data using **nonlinear** least squares - Growth **parameters** are derived from the fit ### Models parameters - $Y_0$: initial value ($log\ CFU/g$) - $\lambda$: length of the lag phase ($h$) - $\mu$: growth rate ($h^{-1}$) - $Y_{max}$: maximum cell growth ($log\ CFU/g$) ## Software ### R software - There are several `R` packages to fit non-linear models - We will use the `predmicror` package were you can find the most frequently used predictive microbiology models - Source code: [https://fsqanalytics.github.io/predmicror/](https://fsqanalytics.github.io/predmicror/) - Full growth models implemented - Baranyi model: [https://fsqanalytics.github.io/predmicror/reference/BaranyiFM.html](https://fsqanalytics.github.io/predmicror/reference/BaranyiFM.html) - Huang model: [https://fsqanalytics.github.io/predmicror/reference/HuangFM.html](https://fsqanalytics.github.io/predmicror/reference/HuangFM.html) - Rosso model: [https://fsqanalytics.github.io/predmicror/reference/RossoFM.html](https://fsqanalytics.github.io/predmicror/reference/RossoFM.html) - Zwietering model: [https://fsqanalytics.github.io/predmicror/reference/ZwieteringFM.html](https://fsqanalytics.github.io/predmicror/reference/ZwieteringFM.html) ## R packages ### Install R packages - First install `devtools` package ::: {.cell exercise='true'}
```{.r .cell-code} install.packages("devtools") library(devtools) ```
::: - Now, install `predmicror`using the `devtools` package - Load the `devtools` package ::: {.cell exercise='true'}
```{.r .cell-code} devtools::install_github('vcadavez/predmicror') ```
::: - Finally, we are ready to load the `predmicror` package and all the predictive microbiology models implemented ::: {.cell exercise='true'}
```{.r .cell-code} library(predmicror) ```
::: ## Experimental growth data - In this example we will use dataset named: `challenge.csv` - The dataset contains results from challenge trials studies - Studies were carried out at constant temperature of 8 $^o$C - The data was obtained from three batches of fermented sausages ### Import the dataset - First, we need to import the data to the `R` environment by using the function `read.csv()` - There are other functions to import data - Check the first lines of the dataset using the function `head()` ::: {.cell exercise='true'}
```{.r .cell-code} df <- read.csv("../data/challenge.csv", sep=";", header=TRUE) head(df) ```
::: ### Check sturcture of the dataset - The function `str()`can be used to inspect the dataset, check the number of rows, columns and the data type inside each column ::: {.cell exercise='true'}
```{.r .cell-code} str(df) ```
::: - The dataset contains three columns - **Lot**: the lot used for the challenge study - **Time**: the duration (hours) of the challenge study - **Counts**: the microbial concentration ($ln\ CFU/g$) ### Plotting data - Plot the `Counts` against `Time`and check the shape of the relationship ::: {.cell exercise='true'}
```{.r .cell-code} plot(Counts ~ Time, data=df, xlab="", ylab="") ```
::: - Clearly, the **Counts** presents a non-linear relationship with **Time** ## Fitting model to data ### Huang model - The Huang full model can be represented as follows $Y = Y_0 +Y_{max} -log \left( e^{Y_0}+(e^{Y_{max}}-e^{Y_0}) \times e^{-mu \times B} \right)$ - The `predmicror` implementation is ::: {.cell exercise='true'}
```{.r .cell-code} HuangFM ```
::: ### Huang model parameters - $Y_0$: initial concentration - $Y_{max}$: maximum concentration - $MU_{max}$: maximum growth rate - $lag$: length of the lag phase - $B$: transition function ### Non-linear least squares - Several `R` packages are available to fit non-linear models - We use the `gsl_nls()` function from `gslnls` package - First, install `gslnls`package ::: {.cell exercise='true'}
```{.r .cell-code} install.packages("gslnls") ```
::: ### Starting values - Fitting non-linear models require the definition of starting values - Thus, first define the starting values of the model parameters ::: {.cell exercise='true'}
```{.r .cell-code} start.values = list( Y0=0, Ymax=22, MUmax=1.7, lag=5 ) start.values ```
::: ### Fit Huang model to Lot 1 data - Now, we are ready to fit the Huang model to the experimental data - Load the `R` packages: `predmicror` and `gslnls` - Fit the model Huang full model (`HuangFM()`) using the `gsl_nls()` function from the `gslnls` package ::: {.cell exercise='true'}
```{.r .cell-code} library(predmicror) library(gslnls) fit <- gsl_nls(Counts ~ HuangFM(Time, Y0, Ymax, MUmax, lag), data = df[df$Lot==1,], start = start.values) fit ```
::: ### Summarise the fitting results - If the fitting is successful, we can check the fitting results using the `summary()` function ::: {.cell exercise.setup='fit' exercise='true'}
```{.r .cell-code} summary(fit) ```
::: ### Extract the fitted model coefficients - It is possible to extract the fitted model coefficients using the `coef()` and store then `coefs`object - The `coefs`object can be accessed and used in other posterior calculations ::: {.cell exercise.setup='fit' exercise='true'}
```{.r .cell-code} coefs <-coef(fit) coefs ```
::: ### Parameters confidence interval - The `confint()` function can be used to extract the parameters confidence interval ::: {.cell exercise.setup='fit' exercise='true'}
```{.r .cell-code} confint(fit) ```
::: ### Compute the fitted values - Use the function `predict()` to obtain the fitted values - Store the fitted values in the `fits` object - Check the fitted values by typing `fits` ::: {.cell exercise.setup='fit' exercise='true'}
```{.r .cell-code} fits <- predict(fit, interval = "prediction", level = 0.95) fits ```
::: ### Convert the fits object to a data frame - To posterior use we cam convert the `fits` object in a data frame by using the `data.frame()` function - Check the structure of the new object by using the `str()` function ::: {.cell exercise.setup='pred' exercise='true'}
```{.r .cell-code} fits <- data.frame(fits) str(fits) ```
::: ### Plot the predicted *versus* observed values - Plot the `Counts` against `Time` using the `plot()` function and subseting for Lot 1 using the argument `data=df[df$Lot==1,]` - Add the fitted and confidence interval lines using the `lines()` function ::: {.cell exercise.setup='preddf' exercise='true'}
```{.r .cell-code} plot(Counts ~ Time, data=df[df$Lot==1,], ylim=c(-2,22)) lines(df[df$Lot==1,]$Time, fits$fit, col="blue") lines(df[df$Lot==1,]$Time, fits$upr, col="red") lines(df[df$Lot==1,]$Time, fits$lwr, col="red") ```
::: ## Now is your Turn! ### Fit the Huang full model to 1. data from **Lot 2** 2. data from **Lot 3** 3. All data 4. Use the model fitted to the complete data set to predict the bacterial **Counts** after $12$ hours of incubation time ### Fit Huang model to `Lot 2` Change the code to fit the Huang full model to data from `Lot 2` ::: {.cell exercise='true' exercise.eval='false'}
```{.r .cell-code} library(predmicror) library(gslnls) fit2 <- gsl_nls(Counts ~ HuangFM(Time, Y0, Ymax, MUmax, lag), data=df[df$Lot==1,], start = list(Y0=0.1, Ymax=22, MUmax=1.7, lag=5) ) fit2 ```
::: ::: {.cell}
```{.r .cell-code} library(predmicror) library(gslnls) fit2 <- gsl_nls(Counts ~ HuangFM(Time, Y0, Ymax, MUmax, lag), data=df[df$Lot==2,], start = list(Y0=0, Ymax=22, MUmax=1.7, lag=5) ) fit2 ```
::: ### Summarise the results Summarise the results of the fitted model ::: {.cell exercise='true' exercise.eval='false' exercise.setup='huang_l2'}
```{.r .cell-code} summary(fit1) ```
::: ::: {.cell}
```{.r .cell-code} summary(fit2) ```
::: ### Fit Huang model to `Lot 3` Change the code to fit the Huang full model to data from `Lot 3` ::: {.cell exercise='true' exercise.eval='false'}
```{.r .cell-code} library(predmicror) library(gslnls) fit3 <- gsl_nls(Counts ~ HuangFM(Time, Y0, Ymax, MUmax, lag), data=df[df$Lot==1,], start = list(Y0=0.1, Ymax=22, MUmax=1.7, lag=5) ) fit3 ```
::: ::: {.cell}
```{.r .cell-code} library(predmicror) library(gslnls) fit3 <- gsl_nls(Counts ~ HuangFM(Time, Y0, Ymax, MUmax, lag), data=df[df$Lot==3,], start = list(Y0=0, Ymax=22, MUmax=1.7, lag=5) ) fit3 ```
::: ### Summarise the results Summarise the results of the fitted model ::: {.cell exercise='true' exercise.eval='false' exercise.setup='huang_l3'}
::: ::: {.cell}
```{.r .cell-code} summary(fit3) ```
::: ### Fit Huang model to all data Change the code to fit the Huang full model to all data ::: {.cell exercise='true' exercise.eval='true'}
```{.r .cell-code} library(predmicror) library(gslnls) fit_all <- gsl_nls(Counts ~ HuangFM(Time, Y0, Ymax, MUmax, lag), data=df[df$Lot==3,], start = list(Y0=0.1, Ymax=22, MUmax=1.7, lag=5) ) fit_all ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Nonlinear regression model model: Counts ~ HuangFM(Time, Y0, Ymax, MUmax, lag) data: df[df$Lot == 3, ] Y0 Ymax MUmax lag 0.5506 22.2955 1.8053 3.0027 residual sum-of-squares: 0.307 Algorithm: multifit/levenberg-marquardt, (scaling: more, solver: qr) Number of iterations to convergence: 5 Achieved convergence tolerance: 6.518e-11 ``` :::
::: ::: {.cell}
::: ### Summarise the results Summarise the results of the fitted model ::: {.cell exercise='true' exercise.eval='false' exercise.setup='huang_all-solution'}
```{.r .cell-code} summary(fit) ```
::: ::: {.cell}
```{.r .cell-code} summary(fit_all) ```
::: ### Predict Counts after 12 hours ::: {.cell exercise='true' exercise.eval='false' exercise.setup='huang_all-solution'}
```{.r .cell-code} predict(fit_, newdata = list(Time=)) ```
::: ::: {.cell}
```{.r .cell-code} predict(fit_all, newdata = list(Time=12)) ```

start.values =  list(Y0=0, Ymax=22, MUmax=1.7, lag=5) 
</script>

preserve.preserveb1ca1f2d6d99a3f5:
<script type="application/shiny-prerendered" data-context="server-extras">
ojs_define <- function(..., .session = shiny::getDefaultReactiveDomain()) {
  quos <- rlang::enquos(...)
  vars <- rlang::list2(...)
  nm <- names(vars)
  if (is.null(nm)) {
    nm <- rep_len("", length(vars))
  }
  mapply(function(q, nm, val) {
    # Infer name, if possible
    if (nm == "") {
      tryCatch({
        nm <- rlang::as_name(q)
      }, error = function(e) {
        code <- paste(collapse = "\n", deparse(rlang::f_rhs(q)))
        stop("ojs_define() could not create a name for the argument: ", code)
      })
    }
    .session$output[[nm]] <- val
    outputOptions(.session$output, nm, suspendWhenHidden = FALSE)
    .session$sendCustomMessage("ojs-export", list(name = nm))
    NULL
  }, quos, nm, vars, SIMPLIFY = FALSE, USE.NAMES = FALSE)
  invisible()
}
</script>
